Title: PETER LOMBARD, SENTENCES. folio verso
Description.note: Physical description:Parchment, one leaf cut vertically in half.  Original measurement 313 x 255 (262 x 170) mm.; A, 313 x 130 (259 x 76) mm.; B, 305 x 127 (255 x 76) mm. B is creased and stained, and is slightly shrunken. 2 columns of 43 lines; ruled in lead point, double bounding lines. One extra line of text at the bottom of Av. Pricking visible on both inner and outer edge of leaf. Written above top line in an uneven romanesque textura script; black ink. A later hand has added “XIX” in left margin of Ar where Distinctio XIX begins.Decoration:Rubrics in red ink, 2-line initials in red, with decorative features but no penwork.  Guide letters visible in outer margins beyond pricking. Authors quoted are cited in the margins in red (Aug., Ber., etc.); two red dots in text show where quotations begin. New sentences marked by slightly decorative 1-line capitals in black ink, often minuscule forms writ large.Provenance:Written in England at the end of twelfth century, to judge from the script. Manuscript dismembered in England by the late 16th century and used to rebind the 1557 edition of Pico della Mirandola’s Opera (Basel: Henricus Petri 1557), employed as reinforcements of first and last quires. Physical traces include a vertical binding fold in what had been center of the leaf on each fragment, with holes for sewing on 5 bands on A and a piece of thread at the top right of Ar. Early modern English history of the printed book is not known. It belonged to the library of the Crozer Theological Seminary (founded 1867) of Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA (book plate no. 208, q P58). Sold by Bucknell at Christie’s London, July 2003. Given to UCLA in 2005.
Description.abstract: One leaf cut in half vertically between the two columns.Contents:A, r:// ad hoc ut sancti essemus ... An filius cum nobis sit datus: possit dici noster ut spiritus sanctus. Hic queritur utrum ... Urtum spiritus sanctus ad se ipsam referatur. Post hec queritur... Hic de equalitate trium personarum. Nunc postquam ... & patri & filio spiritus sanctus [text continues on Br]B, r-v: quia ut Augustinus in libro de fide ad Petrum . . . aliam non excedat supra ostensum est : ubi coeternitas trium personarum . . . Quid eternitas et magnitudo et potentia in deo est unum, licet ponantur quasi diversa. Cumque enumerentur... Hic de magnitudine quod ea aliqua personarum aliam enim excedit. Nunc igitur ... Quomodo dicitur esse pater in filio et filius in patre et spiritus sanctus in utroque et singulus in singulis. Et inde est...ut unus sint in fide nostri uterque [text continues on Av]A, v: non unus nec eundem virumque [sic] nec  ... Ad id quod ceperat redit ut ostendat scilicet quod magnitudine alius alium non superat. Si nun iam ad propositum ... tres quam due, nec maior unus quam //Peter Lombard’s Sentences, Book I, De mysterio trinitatis, from the middle of Distinctio 18.10 to middle of Distinctio 19.6; ed. I. Brady (Grottaferrata 1971-1981).

Title: ANTIPHONAL. folio recto
Description.note: Physical description:Parchment (stiff), 1 leaf. 375 x 295 (320 x 221) mm.  Written in an upright textura. 5-line staff with square notes  Formerly f. 87 (in ink on upper recto). Decoration:Opening initial in red. Two initials M and A with pen cadels, and letters M and A in Roman capitals as either guide letters or aids to legibility.Provenance:Written in Spain in the sixteenth or seventeenth century. Antiphonal dismembered probably in the mid-twentieth century. Gift from Hunter Rouse in the 1950s.Given to UCLA in 2005.
Description.abstract: r-v: //In festo S. Agnetis. Ad Laudes. antiphona. Ingressa Agnes turpitudinis locum Ps. , Dominus reg. A’. Mecum enim habeo ... A.’ Annulo suo subarravit me Dominus meus Jesus Christus et tamquam sponsam de// The beginning of lauds for the feast of St. Agnes (21 January).

Title: BREVIARY, Brigittine use. folio recto
Description.note: Physical description:Parchment, 1 leaf, 177 x 129 (113 x 75) mm. 18 long lines; ruled in brown ink. Written in a heavy gothic littera textualis. Five holes along left edge from the original binding. Decoration:3-line initial, blue with copious red penwork both inside the letter and extending above and below. Geometric designs in white on the letter itself. Rubric in red at the beginning of the new lectio is in the text hand. Letters washed in red throughout. Capitals sometimes have decorative cords.Original manuscript sewn on five cords.Provenance:Written in the Netherlands. The original manuscript was sewn on five cords.Given to UCLA in 2005.
Description.abstract: r-v: // Benedicta tu in mulieribus et benedictus fructus . . . lectio secunda. [major initial] Nulla lingua narrare sufficit quam prudentur . . . in voluntate libertatem habet placandi//The text of the second reading is taken from Book XI of St. Bridget of Sweden’s Revelaciones, chapter 14.1-6.
